Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
January 14, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Barbara Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an initial treatment plan for each resident within 30
calendar days of admission.
One of three youth files reviewed did not have the initial treatment plan completed
within 30 days. The initial treatment plan was one day late.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care,
all of the following information shall be documented in
the case record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
2

Two of four discharged youth files reviewed did not list the address of the new
l ocation where the youths were discharged.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all of
the following information prior to employment or at the
time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee
and which are less than 12 months old.
One of eighteen new employee files reviewed lacked a date on one reference
letter.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all of
the following information prior to employment or at the
time specified in this rule:
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the
institution shall complete a written evaluation of the
convictions that addresses the nature of the conviction,
the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity for the
purpose of determining suitability for employment in the
institution.
Four of eighteen new employee files reviewed documented the evaluation by the
facility determining suitability for employment was completed after the employees
were hired.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were three substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000086 dated 12/11/2024 which found the facility
in non-compliance of a staff member shoving a youth into a wall. The corrective
action plan is pending.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001255 dated 04/25/2024 with CAP approval date
of 11/07/2024 was a result of staff slamming a youth to the ground. The agency
terminated the staff’s employment, provided training to staff to recognize triggers
and when staff should remove themselves from situations when feeling frustrated.
The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL
continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001498 dated 07/12/2024 with CAP approval date
of 11/04/2024 was a result of a staff punching a youth and not removing objects
appropriately from a youth. The agency terminated the staff and provided training
on pat down searches of youth. The agency is currently complying with the CAP
action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted
concerns.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 16 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
2024 Renewal: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period
as a result of the Renewal inspection completed on 1/16/2024. This CAP
contained one violation of CCI Rule 400.4114 for not having adequate
documentation of TB testing prior to hire. The CAP contained action items for
human services staff being retrained and a checklist being developed to prevent
errors. The agency complied with the CAP action steps and compliance was
achieved.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001739 with CAP approval date of 01/17/2025 was
a result of the facility not having a sufficient number of staff on shift to provide
adequate supervision and youth were placed in handcuffs when transported to
their new placement. The agency discharged the youths who required more
4

supervision, intakes were paused, the intake process was changed to interview
potential youth in person or via virtual meeting, the policy was updated to reflect
handcuffs cannot be used and staff were trained on the updated policy. The
agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to
monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000064 with CAP approval date of 01/17/025 was
a result of youth not attending school. The agency has posted for employment
opportunities, combined units so all the youth are in one unit allowing staff to take
youth to school or staff to remain in the unit with youth who are refusing to attend
school and implemented regular meetings with school personnel. The agency is
currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor
CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001671 with CAP approval date of 11/04/2025 was
a result of unwarranted restraints. The agency reviewed licensing rules with the
consultant and training on utilizing more verbal de-escalation techniques was
provided to staff. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps,
and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001670 with CAP approval date of 11/04/2024 was
a result of clothing not being issued and inventory sheets not being completed.
The agency changed when the inventory room will be accessible and provided
training to staff. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and
DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC00001596 with CAP approval date of 11/04/2024
was a result of staff not using the proper technique during a restraint and verbally
threatening a youth. One staff quit, the other staff was terminated, and staff were
trained in appropriate restraint techniques and professionalism. The agency is
currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor
CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001629 with CAP approval date of 09/30/2024 was
a result of the agency not having a recreation policy or health service policy and
procedure. The agency developed both policies and trained staff. The agency is
currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor
CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001256 with CAP approval date of 11/25/2024 was
a result of an unwarranted restraint and the incident report not being completed
within the required timeframe. The agency provided additional training to staff on
restraints and completing incident reports. The agency is currently complying with
the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no
noted concerns.
5

Special Investigation 2024SIC0001251 with CAP approval date of 11/25/2024 was
a result of an unwarranted restraint and staff failing to follow the child protection
law. The agency implemented the chief administrator reviewing restraints on
camera, training staff of the child protection law and a staff being terminated. The
agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to
monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001440 with CAP approval date of 11/15/2024 was
a result of the agency not storing lighter fluid appropriately. The agency
implemented vehicle pre/post inspection forms to be completed by staff prior to
transporting youth and provided training to staff on the use of the forms. The
agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to
monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001356 with CAP approval date of 11/07/2024 was
a result of staff not using the appropriate restraint technique. The agency met with
DCWL to discuss appropriate restraint techniques and provided training to staff.
The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL
continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2024C00001053 with CAP approval date of 03/18/2024 was
a result of the agency not making AWOL notifications within the required
timeframes. The agency updated their policy and trained staff. The agency
complied with the CAP action steps and compliance was achieved.
Special Investigation 2024C0001111 with CAP approval date of 03/11/2024 was a
result of the agency not dispensing medication appropriately. The agency
conducted weekly reviews of MARs and training on how to dispense medication
when off site. The agency complied with the CAP action steps and compliance
was achieved.
Financial Overview
The Agency’s annual third-party audit report for fiscal year ending December 31,
2023, was reviewed by the Bureau of Audit. The audit report included financial
concerns. Special investigation 2024SIC0001631 reviewed the financial concerns
and determined no licensing violations. The facilities financial condition will
continue to be monitored in subsequent audits.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
6

The Chief Administrator Assessment was submitted and reviewed. Chief
Administrator reported the program changed to juvenile justice on July 1, 2024, a
new Chief Administrator was assigned to the facility and the previous Chief
Administrator’s decisions were re-evaluated. The intake process for referrals is
more in depth and working to ensure the youth who are placed at the facility are a
better match.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported there have been many changes over the past few months and they
now feel supported by administration after several youth have left, and they have
not gained additional youth. Staff reported they are hopeful with the new staff and
supervisors that have been hired or promoted they are in a better place to start
accepting additional youth into the program. Staff have voiced concerns about
ensuring the youth they admit into the program are a good fit for an open treatment
program and have a willingness to work the program expectations. The staff
members were able to identify new trainings that have assisted in the growth of the
program over the past few months. Staff overall have no concerns about the
current functioning of the program.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. Youth report they would
like a salad bar during meals but that the other food is "alright". The youth reported
all staff are supportive and they had no concerns with treatment by staff,
supervisors, or administration. Youth reported having all of their basic needs met as
well as weekly therapy sessions and contact throughout the week with their case
manager. Youth did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on January 14, 2025.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
